_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Facility:    AgChoice - North
Location:    17287 West Hwy 136, Rock Port, Mo.
Contact:     Jason Brown
Phone:     660-744-6289

1. The Facility Policy

    MFA Incorporated, and the employees of the AgChoice - North in Rock Port are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Rock Port Volunteer Rural Fire Department, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility Information

    The primary activity at the facility is the receiving, storage and distribution of bulk dry/liquid fertilizer and anhydrous ammonia for direct application as a crop nutrient.  This facility also handles bulk and package pesticides for field crops.

    The maximum quantity stored would be 560,784 pounds in our four 30,000 gallon storage tanks. The facility has twenty 1,000 gallon nurse tanks, seven double 1,000 gallon nurse tanks, and 52 1,500 gallon nurse tanks, therefore the facility total maximum storage would be 933,594 pounds.

3. The Accidental Release Prevention Program.

    The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, 1981", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., the Missouri Anhydrous Ammonia Law, and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". The facility will adopt changes required to meet the 1999 ANSI Code as budgets and time will allow.

4. The Five-year Accident History

    There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environ

mental damage.

5. The Emergency Response Program.

    The facility has;

    a. a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA
       Standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;

    b. provided State and Local authorities with the emergency
       planning and community right-to-know information as
       required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

    c. a written emergency response program, in accordance with
       OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 1910.120, including pre-emergency
       planning and employee training.

6. Planned changes to improve safety.

    Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.



    3/23/07
